case_name: Rani Purnima Debi v. Kumar Khagendra Narayan Deb

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 373/587 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated February 2, 1954, of the Assam High Court in First Appeal No. 19 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 373/587 Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated February 2, 1954, of the Assam High Court in First Appeal No. 19 of 1950  Probate . P. Desai and Naunit Lal, for the appellants. R. Krishnaswami, for respondent No. 1. 1961. August,22.

facts.text: The main appellant is Rani Purnima-Debi, widow of Kumar Chandra Narayan Deb, the testator, who died in June 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The main appellant is Rani Purnima- Debi widow of Kumar Chandra Narayan. Deb  hereinafter called the testator , who died in June 1946. The second appellant is the testators married daughter.

facts.text: The second appellant is the testator's married daughter.

anchor.surface_text: The second appellant is the testators married daughter. And application was made by Kumar Khagendra Narayan Deb  hereinafter referred to as the respondent  before the District Delegate, Gauhati in August 1946 for grant of letters of administration with the will annexed.

facts.text: Application was made by Kumar Khagendra Narayan Deb (respondent) before the District Delegate, Gauhati in August 1946 for grant of letters of administration with the will annexed.

anchor.surface_text: And application was made by Kumar Khagendra Narayan Deb  hereinafter referred to as the respondent  before the District Delegate, Gauhati in August 1946 for grant of letters of administration with the will annexed. The case of the respondent was that the testator had executed,a.will on December 29, 1943, in favour of the respondent by which the, testator gave his ,entire property to the respondent subject to the respondents maintaining the testators widow and sister.

facts.text: The testator executed a will on December 29, 1943, in favour of the respondent, giving his entire property to the respondent subject to the respondent maintaining the testator's widow and sister.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the respondent was that the testator had executed,a.will on December 29, 1943, in favour of the respondent by which the, testator gave his ,entire property to the respondent subject to the respondents maintaining the testators widow and sister. Objections were filed on behalf of the appellants to the grant of letters of administration on the basis of the will propounded by the respondent and three main grounds were urged in that companynection, namely-

facts.text: Objections filed by appellants to grant of letters of administration: (i) will not duly and legally executed and attested, (ii) testator had no sound disposing mind, (iii) will outcome of undue influence and coercion by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Objections were filed on behalf of the appellants to the grant of letters of administration on the basis of the will propounded by the respondent and three main grounds were urged in that companynection, namely- i  that the will was number duly and legally.executed and attested,  ii  that the testator had numbersound disposing mind at the time he executed the will, and that the will was the ,outcome of unite influence and companyrcion exercised by the respondent.

facts.text: Another application for probate of another will executed a few months before testator's death made by Kumar Dwijendra Narayan Deb.

anchor.surface_text: While the application of the respondent was pending, another application for probate of another will said to have been executed by the testator a few months before his death was made by Kumar Dwijendra Narayan Deb. The appellants- objected to that will also on the same grounds and further added that will was a forgery Dwjendra Narayan did number dispute the execution of the will. in favour of the respondent but companytended that will had been revoked by the later will in his favour.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge at Gauhati tried the two suits together: held will of Dwijendra not genuine, dismissed his application; held respondent's will duly executed, attested, sound mind, no undue influence, granted letters of administration to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The two suits arising out of the two applications for probate were. eventually tried together by the Subordinate Judge at Gauhati. He held that the, will propounded by Kumar Dwijendra Narayan Deb was number genuine and therefore dismissed his application. As to the win propounded by the, respondent it was held that it was duly executed and attested and was made by the testator at a time when he had sound disposing state of mind and that it was number made under any undue influence and companyrcion. Consequently the application of the respondent was allowed and letters of administration With the companyy of the will annexed were ordered to be issued to him.

facts.text: Three appeals to Assam High Court: one by present appellants contesting letters to respondent; two by Dwijendra contesting letters to respondent and genuineness of his own will.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by three appeals to the High Court. One of the appeals was by the present appellants and they companytested the issue of letters of administration in favour of the resp ondent the other two appeals were by Kumar Dwijendra Narayan Deb. By one appeal he companytested the issue of letters of administration to the respondent and by the other he companytested the finding of the Subordinate Judge that the will propounded-by him was number genuine.

facts.text: Assam High Court upheld trial court: Dwijendra's will not genuine, dismissed his appeals; upheld respondent's will, dismissed appellants' appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The three appeals were heard by the High Court together and it upheld the finding of the trial companyrt that the will in favour of Dwijendra Narayan was number genuine in companysequence, the,. two appears filed by him were dismissed. ... In the appeal. by the appellants, the High Court upheld the findings of the trial companyrt and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: High Court noted suspicious circumstances but held registration in January 1944 dispelled suspicion.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was companyscious of the fact that there were certain suspicious circumstances attending the execution of the , will in favour of the respondent, but it held that as the will pro- pounded by the respondent was later registered in January 1944 the suspicion attending the execution of the will was dispelled by the fact of registration.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave granted, judgment delivered August 22, 1961 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. August,22. The judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the Assam High Court in a probate matter.

facts.text: Testator left widow (appellant), married daughter (appellant), unmarried sister dependent on him, nearer relations closer than respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The testator left behind him his widow and his married daughter  who are appellants before us  and an unmarried sister who was dependent upon him. Besides these, the testator had a number of other relations who were much nearer to him than the respondent.

facts.text: Will provides only that respondent suitably maintain widow and sister during lifetime, no specified amount or charge on properties.

anchor.surface_text: Even if we leave out of account the married daughter and the other nearer relations, the widow-,and, the, sister were certainly expected to be properlyprovided for by the testator. It is number in dispute thatthe relations between the testator and his wife and sister were good. ... All that the will says is that the wife and the sister would be suitably maintained by the respondent during their life-time. No amount is specified which should be given to these two ladies as maintenance and numbercharge is created on the properties left by the testator which were companysiderable.

facts.text: Will completely disinherits daughter.

anchor.surface_text: In effect, the two ladies were left to the tender mercies of the respondent in the matter of their maintenance. Further the result of this will is that the daughter would be companypletely disinherited.

facts.text: Relations between testator and wife/sister good; not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute thatthe relations between the testator and his wife and sister were good.

facts.text: Will registered on January 27, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that this will was registered on January 27, 1944, and there is an endorsement on the will to the effect that the testator had admitted the execution of it.

facts.text: Suspicious circumstances: unnatural will, respondent benefits solely and took part in execution, shaky signature, testator signed blank papers, different ink.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that there., were suspicious circumstances attending the execution of the will and that it was an unnatural will. ... Another suspicious circumstance is that the signature of the testator does number appear to be his usual signature. ... the High Court has numbericed that the signature of the testator is number in the same ink...

facts.text: Only three attesting witnesses examined: all interested (Bhattacharya purohit, Kulendra cousin, Sarma lawyer for respondent).

anchor.surface_text: These three attesting witnesses are Biswanath Bhattacharya, Rameswar Sarma, and Kulendra Narayan Deb. None of these witnesses is independent...

facts.text: Supreme Court holds propounder failed to dispel suspicious circumstances, due execution and attestation not proved, appeal allowed, letters not granted.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside. the .judgments of the High Court and the trial companyrt and dismiss the suit arising out of the application for probate made by the respondent.

arguments.claim: Evidence inadequate despite pleadings not alleging forgery explicitly

anchor.surface_text: We are further of the opinion that the High Court was number justified in executing the inadequacy of the evidence to prove the due execution and attestation of the will on the basis of the pleadings of the parties.

holdings.text: We are therefore not satisfied about the due execution and attestation of this will by the testator and hold that the propounder has been unable to dispel the suspicious circumstances which surround the execution and attestation of this will.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore not satisfied about the due execution and attestation of this will by the testator and hold that the propounder has been unable to dispel the suspicious circumstances which surround the execution and attestation of this will.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suspicious circumstances (unnatural will, propounder involvement, shaky signature, blank papers available, different ink) not dispelled by interested and contradictory attesting witnesses; registration evidence perfunctory without proof testator knew contents.

holdings.text: Looking at the evidence of the three attesting witnesses and the respondent broadly, we must say that evidence does not dispel the suspicion as to the due execution and attestation of this will.

anchor.surface_text: Looking at the evidence of the three attesting witnesses and the respondent broadly, we must say that evidence does number dispel the suspicion as to the due execution and attestation of this will.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Attesting witnesses interested (purohit, cousin, respondent's lawyer); contradictions on key facts like presence of testator's wife; no independent witnesses produced despite availability.

holdings.text: We are further of the opinion that the High Court was not justified in excusing the inadequacy of the evidence to prove the due execution and attestation of the will on the basis of the pleadings of the parties.

anchor.surface_text: We are further of the opinion that the High Court was number justified in excusing the inadequacy of the evidence to prove the due execution and attestation of the will on the basis of the pleadings of the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants required strict proof of execution despite not alleging forgery explicitly; suspicious circumstances necessitated satisfactory evidence from propounder regardless of pleadings.

holdings.text: Therefore we are left with the bald fact of registration which in our opinion is insufficient in the circumstances of this case to dispel the suspicious circumstances which we have enumerated above.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore we are left with the bald fact of registration which in our opinion is insufficient in the circumstances of this case to dispel the suspicious circumstances which we have enumerated above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of registration process perfunctory; no proof contents read over or testator understood it was a will; mere admission of execution and endorsement inadequate.

holdings.text: If therefore these two witnesses, namely, Arabali and Dehiram Bora are to be treated as attesting witnesses for the purpose of s.63 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925 (39 of 1925), it is clear that they completely fail to prove due execution and attestation of the Will as required by that section.

anchor.surface_text: If therefore these two witnesses, namely, Arabali and Dehiram Bora are to be treated as attesting witnesses for the purpose of s.63 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925 (39 of 1925), it is clear that they companypletely fail to prove due execution and attestation of the Will as required by that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence will read over, testator admitted execution knowingly, or mutual presence for attestation; only bald admission and identification.

holdings.text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgments of the High Court and the trial court and dismiss the suit arising out of the application for probate made by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside. the .judgments of the High Court and the trial companyrt and dismiss the suit arising out of the application for probate made by the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative failure to prove due execution and attestation due to unremoved suspicious circumstances.

precedents.citation: H. Venkatachala Iyengar v. B. N. Thimmajamma 1

anchor.surface_text: H. Venkatachala Iyengar v. B. N. Thimmajamma 1 . It was observed in that case that the mode of proving a will did number ordinarily differ from that of proving any other document except as to the special requirement of attestation prescribed in the case of a will by s.63 of the Indian Succession Act.

precedents.case_name: H. Venkatachala Iyengar v. B. N. Thimmajamma
precedents.cited_proposition: Principles governing proof of a will: onus on propounder to prove execution, attestation, capacity; additional onus to dispel suspicious circumstances; examples of suspicious circumstances including shaky signature, feeble mind, unnatural dispositions, propounder taking prominent part

precedents.citation: Vellasaway Sarvai v. L. Sivaraman Servai,  1

anchor.surface_text: Vellasaway Sarvai v. L. Sivaraman Servai,  1  Surendra Nath Lahiri v. Jnanendra Nath Lahiri   2  and Girji Datt Singh v. Gangotri Datt Singh  3 . Therefore, the mere fact of registration may number by itself be enough to dispel all suspicion that may attach to the execution and attestation of a will

precedents.case_name: Vellaswamy Servai v. L. Sivaraman Servai

Therefore, the mere fact of registration may number by itself be enough to dispel all suspicion that may attach to the execution and attestation of a will though the fact that there has been registration would be an important circumstance

precedents.case_name: Surendra Nath Lahiri v. Jnanendra Nath Lahiri
precedents.cited_proposition: Example of a case where a registered will was not acted upon (not held genuine)

precedents.citation: Girji Datt Singh v. Gangotri Datt Singh  3

anchor.surface_text: Girji Datt Singh v. Gangotri Datt Singh  3 . Therefore, the mere fact of registration may number by itself be enough to dispel all suspicion that may attach to the execution and attestation of a will though the fact that there has been registration would be an important circumstance in favour of the will being genuine
